evaluation.response:
Welcome. Lots of cardiologists struggle with exactly this—sleep fragmentation, circadian whiplash, and a busy brain after cases. We can set up a simple, repeatable plan you can use on off-call weeks and adapt during call.

A few quick questions to tailor it:
- What’s your call pattern (in-house vs home, nights vs 24-hr, consecutive days)?
- Biggest issue: falling asleep, staying asleep after pages, or waking too early?
- Caffeine habits (timing/amount), alcohol, and exercise?
- Sleep environment: blackout, noise, temperature, pager/phone setup?

Quick-start plan you can use tonight
- Anchor wake time: Pick a wake time you can keep within ±30 min most days (even post-call, see recovery plan).
- Light and caffeine: Get 10–20 min of outdoor light within an hour of waking. Delay first caffeine by 60–90 min if possible; stop caffeine 8 hours before target bedtime on non-call days.
- Evening wind-down (20–30 min): Dim lights/blue-light filters, warm shower, then:
  - 5–10 min progressive muscle relaxation (tense–release each muscle group).
  - 2–3 min “brain dump”: write tomorrow’s to-do’s and one worry with a next action.
- In-bed rules (CBT-I basics): If awake >20 min or mentally “revved,” get up and read something dull in low light; return when sleepy. No clock-watching.

On-call tactics
- Pre-call “prophylactic” nap: 20 min or a full 90 min, ending 3–4 hours before start time.
- Strategic caffeine: 100–200 mg at start; if overnight, another 100 mg around 2–3 a.m. Avoid within 6 hours of intended sleep.
- During pages: Keep lights low/amber, avoid email/screens. Use a white-noise machine to mask random noise (keep pager on vibrate + loud).
- Rapid downshift to fall back asleep (2–3 min):
  - Do 3–5 “physiological sighs” (inhale through nose, small top-up inhale, long slow mouth exhale).
  - Then a quick body scan from feet to head, relaxing each area on exhale.
- If multiple awakenings: Accept shorter, cumulative sleep. Grab 10–20 min “power naps” when safe; set two alarms.

Recovery after a rough night
- If coming off an overnight: Block 3–4 hours of sleep as soon as you get home; wake by early afternoon. Get sunlight on waking. Aim for an early, regular bedtime that night.
- If day sleep is needed: Cool, very dark room (eye mask/blackout), 65–68°F if possible. Sunglasses on the commute home to reduce alerting light.
- Optional melatonin: 0.5–1 mg 1–2 hours before the intended sleep episode (helps with phase shifting and day-sleep); avoid higher doses to reduce grogginess.

Environment upgrades that pay off
- Darkness: Blackout curtains or eye mask; cover LEDs.
- Noise: White noise or fan; quiet HVAC; soft silicone earplugs if you can still perceive pager vibration.
- Bedding and temp: Cool room, breathable bedding. Consider a cooling pillow/mattress topper if you sleep hot.

Stress regulation you can actually use between cases
- One-minute reset: 6 slow breaths (about 5–6 per minute), long exhale emphasis.
- Two-minute tension release: Shrug/tense shoulders 5 seconds, release 15; repeat down the body.
- Five-minute focus: Box breathing (4-4-4-4) or a brief body scan. Good between cases to reduce carryover arousal.

Habits that protect sleep
- Exercise most days, but keep vigorous work within 3–4 hours of bedtime on non-call days.
- Alcohol: Even 1–2 drinks fragment sleep; avoid within 3–4 hours of bedtime when you need high-quality sleep.
- Don’t try to “catch up” by sleeping half the day; use an anchor wake time and add a short afternoon nap if needed.

If you only do three things this week
- Keep a consistent wake time and get morning outdoor light.

- Do a 20-minute wind-down with dim light + progressive muscle relaxation + brain dump.

- Park-it note: Voice memo or 1-line note with any pending tasks/worries. Set a reminder time. Tell yourself, “Handled for now.”

Doorway reset (2–3 minutes before entering home)
- Posture + pec release: Doorframe stretch 30 sec each side; slow neck rolls.
- State shift cue: One deep inhale, long exhale, say quietly “Work mode off, home mode on.”
- Phone in a basket on Do Not Disturb for the first 15 minutes at home (exceptions for true STATs).

Quick body downshift (90 seconds)
- Shake it out for 20–30 seconds (arms/legs), then 10 slow squats or wall push-ups to burn residual adrenaline.

Hot–cold face reset (1–2 minutes)
- Warm water on neck/shoulders for relaxation, then 30–60 seconds of cool water splashed on the face (cheeks/under eyes) or a cool pack. Triggers the dive reflex and blunts sympathetic arousal.

Rapid mental debrief (2 minutes)
- 3–2–1: Three things went well, two things to adjust next time, one thing you’re letting go tonight. Keep it factual; no self-critique spiral. Close the note.

Late-case → bed mini-routine (8–10 minutes)
- Lights low/amber as soon as you leave work areas; avoid email and bright screens.
- Quick shower (warm), then 5 minutes of progressive muscle relaxation in bed.
- If mind is busy: write a “worry list” + next tiny action for each, close notebook.
- Optional: 0.5–1 mg melatonin 1–2 hours before intended sleep if your schedule is shifted; avoid alcohol and caffeine.

Family-friendly arrival ritual (3 minutes)
- Hydrate, hug for 20 seconds (oxytocin helps), three slow breaths together.
- Agree on a 10–15 minute buffer before heavy conversations if you’ve had a tough case.

Micro-resets you can use between cases
- One-minute breath: 6 breaths/minute with long exhales.
- Two-minute tension release: Tense a muscle group for 5 sec, release for 15; scan head to toe.
- 60-second “name and park”: Label the dominant thought (“planning,” “worry”), jot it, move on.

Tips to make it stick
- Tie your chosen routine to fixed cues: touching the car door handle, your front doormat, or turning off your ID badge.
- Keep a “transition kit” in your bag: index cards or a small notebook, eye drops, lip balm, a protein bar, and a cool pack.

6. **Avoid Heavy Meals Close to Bedtime**: Give your body time to digest.

7. **Create a Sleep-Conducive Environment**: Make your bedroom dark, quiet, and cool. Consider blackout curtains, earplugs, a white noise machine, or an air conditioner. For sleep disorders like insomnia or sleep apnea seek help from a Health Care Professional.

Wishing you restful nights and productive days.

Wishing you moments of calm in the chaos.

It's okay to not be okay, and seeking support is a sign of strength, not weakness. Remember, you don't have to face everything alone. Your loved ones are there for you, just as you are for them.
